title: Compiler emits `warning: value assigned is never read` even though it is read

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-incorrect
labels.description: A diagnostic that is giving misleading or incorrect information

body:
I tried this code: ```rust let mut first = true; for value in some_iterator{ if first{ first = !first; //value assigned to `first` is never read //some logic }else{ //some other logic } } ``` As you see the value of `first` is read in the if statement and then immediately inverted so that there's different behavior on the first iteration of the loop. the compiler emits ``warning: value assigned to `first` is never read`` on the line where `first` is inverted, even though it is read. ### Meta The same behavior happens when building with `+nightly` `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` rustc 1.52.1 (9bc8c42bb 2021-05-09) binary: rustc commit-hash: 9bc8c42bb2f19e745a63f3445f1ac248fb015e53 commit-date: 2021-05-09 host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu release: 1.52.1 LLVM version: 12.0.0 ```
Backtrace

don't mind the sw warning. ``` ❯ RUST_BACKTRACE=1 cargo build Blocking waiting for file lock on build directory Compiling v0.1.0 () warning: unused variable: `sw` --> src/table.rs:22:21 | 22 | let sw = sheet_writer; | ^^ help: if this is intentional, prefix it with an underscore: `_sw` | = note: `#[warn(unused_variables)]` on by default warning: value assigned to `first` is never read --> src/table.rs:27:25 | 27 | first = !first; | ^^^^^ | = note: `#[warn(unused_assignments)]` on by default = help: maybe it is overwritten before being read? warning: 2 warnings emitted Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 20.80s ```
